plants.name: Rudbeckia hirta
plants.description: A hardy perennial or biennial native to North America, producing bright yellow to orange daisy-like flowers with dark brown central cones. It thrives in prairies, meadows, and gardens, attracting butterflies and bees.
plants.funFact: Black-eyed Susans are often used in wildflower mixes to help restore prairie habitats and support pollinator populations.

plants.name: Dahlia pinnata
plants.description: A tuberous-rooted perennial native to Mexico, famed for its large, spectacular blooms in various forms and colors. Dahlias are widely cultivated in gardens and bloom profusely from midsummer through fall.
plants.location: Mexico and widely cultivated in temperate zones worldwide
plants.funFact: Dahlias are the national flower of Mexico and have over 42 species and thousands of cultivars bred for diverse flower shapes.

plants.name: Cyclamen hederifolium
plants.description: A tuberous perennial native to the Mediterranean region, blooming in autumn with delicate upswept pink or white flowers and intricately patterned heart-shaped leaves. It grows well in shady woodland gardens.
plants.funFact: Cyclamen hederifolium flowers open in the afternoon and close at night, a behavior known as nyctinasty.

plants.name: Leucospermum cordifolium
plants.description: An evergreen shrub native to South Africa's Western Cape, producing unique bright orange to red pincushion-like flowers with long styles. It blooms in late winter to spring in its native region but correlates with early autumn blooms in the Southern Hemisphere.
plants.funFact: Pincushion Proteas get their name from their flowers that resemble a pincushion filled with pins due to their long, striking styles.
